titleproper.value:
Guide to the Kathleen Hill Family Collection
                    <num>AIA.064</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Rachel Searcy

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2014-06-02T11:20-0400</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
This collection consists of personal family artifacts belonging to Kathleen Hill, including a photo album, travel diary, and publication of 
                <emph render="italic">The Following of Christ</emph> by Thomas a Kempis. The photograph album and travel diary were produced by Kathleen Carmody, Ms. Hill’s grandmother, during a trip made to Europe in 1903. The diary, which contains a narrative of her vacation, also includes drawings, poetry, souvenirs, and postcards. She describes the details of travel, places visited, people met, along with her impressions of the customs and cultural differences.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Kathleen Hill Family Collection; AIA 064; box number; folder number; Archives of Irish America, Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Kathleen Hill in 2011. The accession number associated with this gift is 2011.050.
This collection contains materials from Kathleen Hill, her grandmother Kathleen Carmody, and her great-grandmother Mary McDonagh.

This collection consists of personal family artifacts belonging to Kathleen Hill, including a photo album, travel diary, and publication of 
                <emph render="italic">The Following of Christ</emph> by Thomas a Kempis. The photograph album and travel diary were produced by Kathleen Carmody, Ms. Hill’s grandmother, during a trip made to Europe in 1903. The diary, which contains a narrative of her vacation, also includes drawings, poetry, souvenirs, and postcards. She describes the details of travel, places visited, people met, along with her impressions of the customs and cultural differences. The collection also contains a theological book belonging to Ms. Hill’s great grandmother, Mary McDonagh, who emigrated from County Roscomman during The Great Famine.
